_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan

Enterprise Mankato Terminal & Storage

Risk Management Plan (RMP)

 Executive Summary



At the Enterprise Mankato Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.



The Enterprise Mankato Terminal and Storage is segregated into two separate storage facilities.  The hydrocarbon portion of the facility is owned by Enterprise Terminal & Storage, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC and operated by Enterprise Products Operating L.P.  The anhydrous ammonia portion of the facility is owned by Magellan Ammonia Pipeline, L.P. and operated by Enterprise Products Operating L.P.



We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:



* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved

* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases

* Emergency Response Programs

* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Mankato Terminal that are regulated by EPA?s RMP rule.  



Facility Description



The Mankato facility is a pipeline, storage and transport truck loading facility.  The pipeline system is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and aqueous ammonia pipeline

system which is regulated by the Department of Transportation.  The propane and ammonia storage/loading facilities are regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.



The Mankato Terminal has three pipelines that are routed through the facility and are regulated by the Department of Transportation.  These three pipelines are in part, a mix product line (natural gasoline, naphtha, normal butane, iso-butane and propane), a dedicated propane line and a dedicated anhydrous ammonia line which is owned by Magellan Ammonia Pipeline, L.P. (Magellan) and operated by Enterprise Products Operating L.P.  In addition, the facility receives propane from the pipeline to four 90,000 gallon capacity storage tanks.  These tanks are used for distribution to the truck transport loading docks which also has capabilities to stench the propane for retail sales companies.



The Magellan ammonia system receives ammonia product off of the ammonia pipeline and is thus routed to their three tanks which are two 90,000 gallon tanks and a single 63,000 gallon tank.  In addition to the same ammonia system, a portion of the ammonia product can be routed to a cold storage tank which is owned and operated by Koch Nitrogen Company (Koch) with limited operations by Enterprise.  Koch is accountable to file their own RMP for their assets and therefore is only mentioned for the purpose of the facility description.



All of the previously mentioned tanks (propane and ammonia) are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed a maximum capacity of 80%.



In our facility we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Toxics



Anhydrous ammonia is transported and stored at the facility via a dedicated anhydrous ammonia pipeline.  The material from this tank is routed to the truck transport

loading for wholesale distribution to anhydrous ammonia retailers.



Flammables



Propane is a finished product which can be delivered into four storage tanks via the dedicated propane pipeline, or the mixed product pipeline.  This material is routed from these tanks to the truck transport loading docks for whole sale to propane retailers.



A small quantity of Ethyl Mercaptan is used to stench the propane at the truck transport docks.



Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios



The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.



Worst Case Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical



This simulation involves a complete failure of two of the three anhydrous ammonia storage tanks.  The scenario assumes there would be no mitigation.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting of the Risk Management Plan.



Alternate Release Scenario(s) ? Regulated Toxic Chemical



The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the transfer loading hose on the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 2,500 pounds per minutes for 10 minutes after the hose break.  The simulation calculated that 25,000 pounds of material were released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  The measures consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff val

ves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the data elements.



Worse Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals



This simulation involves the rupture or failure of the propane storage tanks resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  Inventory from all four tanks are simulated due to the proximity of the tanks relative to mitigation to the simulation.  This scenario would not be mitigated due to the type of scenario modeled.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting of the Risk Management Plan



Alternate Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals



The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 500 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the line break.  The simulation calculated that 30,500 pounds of material were released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  This consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  This scenario would be mitigated due to the type of scenario modeled.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the m

aterial and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the data elements.



We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.



Emergency Response Program



Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Blue Earth County Emergency Management Director, which includes the local Police department, Sheriff?s Department, Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.



In the event of an accidental release, the local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the emergency notification alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Blue Earth County Sheriff?s Department and local Fire Departments.  Remote activation can also be accomplished from the system?s control center which is based in Houston, Texas.  The Enterprise Houston Control Center has area video cameras with dial-up access.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shutdown remotely from Houston Control or locally by Operation.  A third party contractor, 3E is under contract to effectively contact the necessary agencies if required.  



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Enterprise Products takes a systematic,

protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  The Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:



* Process safety information

* Process hazard analysis

* Operating procedures

* Training

* Mechanical integrity

* Management of change

* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"

* Compliance audits

* Incident investigation

* Employee participation

* Hot work permit

* Contractors



As a part of the prevention efforts, there are a multitude of programs in which Enterprise employees participate.  A training program has been developed in which the Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.



There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.



The Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.



The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise Products Operating L.P. is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.



Accident History



Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following is a list of reviews and/or i

mprovements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



* The PSM system is constantly being subjected to critical reviews with an objective of improving the programs.

* The written PSM management system is presently undergoing a comprehensive, thorough review, with specific emphasis being placed on the written mechanical integrity program.

* The Emergency Preparedness Plan is presently being reviewed and updated and will be coordinated with local officials when complete.

* The Safety Procedures and Policies Manual is presently being reviewed and updated and should be completed in the fall of 2005.





RMP Executive Summary    Page 1 of 5    4/25/2005
